post_title: In which Éomer, in an attempt to cover a minor mess, manages to create a greater one… one that could easily spark some gossip at court.
comment:
If anyone—a kitchen boy, a maid, or, Eru forbid, even the housekeeper Wynhild—had wandered near the pantry in the quiet hour just before dawn, they would have heard a muffled exchange from the depths of the storeroom:
“Try shifting this bowl here…”
“Easy, you’re you're on me.”
“Oh, does that bother you, my lady?”
“Get off me; I can’t pull it out!”
“Perhaps if you lean a little this way…”
“It won’t fit… it’s too big!”
Éomer let out a quiet chuckle, at which Lothíriel, half-crouched within the pantry shelf and half outside it, rolled her eyes with a huff.
“Valandil, you’re so childish.”
“Hey, I’m the King of Rohan, you know!”
“A twelve-year-old king, apparently.”
The two figures were rather indecently close, barefoot and dressed only in light nightclothes. They had ventured into the kitchens with the hope of finding them still deserted for a late-night snack or an early breakfast. With uncharacteristic gentleness, Éomer shifted his wife’s warm figure, promising himself to show her more vigorous attentions later.
“Let me do it. There it is… if I just pull like this…”
With a heavy thud, Éomer tumbled backward, and Lothíriel stifled a snicker. He quickly scrambled up, rubbing his bruised rear, but soon raised in triumph the cause of their entire escapade:
“Behold, my dear: an authentic roll of cured venison, made by the skilled hands of our spice masters. No need to thank me for such a delicacy.”
Lothíriel watched her royal husband with a half-incredulous, half-amused smile, as he held the large salami with the pride of a merchant at the autumn fair. All of this because they had engaged in a lighthearted debate over the delicacies of their respective homelands, and Éomer had insisted on making her taste his beloved homeland treat without delay, as though he himself had crafted it. Now holding his prize, Éomer took her hand and said:
“Let’s get out of here.”
His large, bare feet thudded heavily along the wooden planks of the hallways, while Lothíriel tiptoed behind him, her thin nightgown fluttering in her wake. Once safely behind their chamber door, Éomer let out a relieved sigh.
“Thank Béma that Wynhild didn’t catch us, or she’d have given me a hard time, king or not.”
Lothíriel laughed at the thought; in truth, the old housekeeper of Edoras scared her, though Wynhild had been nothing but sweet and kind to her.
“But have we gotten the servants into trouble? I’d hate to think someone else might pay for our, well, indiscretions.”
Éomer, who had already taken a hearty bite of the salami and was chewing contentedly, paused to think. To Lothíriel, he looked like a great golden-haired squirrel with the morsel stuffed in one cheek. How he could be both a fierce warrior and a wise sovereign as well, was a mystery she had yet to solve. His voice came out muffled as he swallowed.
“You’re right, but if it ever gets out, I’ll say the sweet Queen of the Mark was struck by an irresistible craving for spiced meat in the dead of night—and who would deny anything to the future mother of the next royal heir?”
He crossed his arms, looking quite pleased with his idea, but Lothíriel’s eyes widened at the bold lie, and she covered her face with her hand, foreseeing trouble ahead.
writing_prompt: Late at night, the King of Rohan and his queen sneak into the pantry for a forbidden snack, only to find that stealing cured venison is far more complicated—and far more amusing—than they anticipated.

comment:
The white Elven ship rode the golden waves that rolled around its hull, the low sunlight casting iridescent rainbows upon the pearly foam, and the gulls cried as they circled around the swan-shaped figurehead. A solitary Elf had long been leaning against the railing, gazing at what was no longer in sight. Jet-black hair, simply braided, hid a face marked more by experience than by the long passage of years.
“Why do your eyes, which always looked forward, now turn back?”
A female voice interrupted his reverie, and a tall, golden-haired figure approached him, her hair gleaming like starlight. He replied in a somber tone:
“Truly, they see only a liquid curtain of silver, my dear friend.”
“Tears, Elrond?”
Galadriel’s hand came to rest beside Elrond's, and the stones of Nenya and Vilya glimmered faintly; the rings, once so powerful, now bereft of their forged powers, yet not of the memories they carried. At last, Elrond turned his face toward Galadriel. They had known each other for so long, through entire ages in which unimaginable things had occurred, that their bond transcended the very concept of friendship. She smiled gently at him, waiting for a response, and the Elf shook his raven braids, shrugging his shoulders:
“For all these years, we have, I have done nothing but look and sigh for Aman like the rest of my people, and yet I have fought and suffered indescribably for this Middle-earth. I do not know, it seems to me that I have left behind more than I will ever find in the Blessed Land… I have left her behind.”
Elrond finished in a whisper, the pain for his lost daughter weighing on his shoulders, and he bowed his head to hide the anguished expression on his lips. Galadriel laid her hand on his in silent understanding:
“Arwen has made her choice, as you made yours: she has chosen a mortal life, and long and painful will be her years of solitude. She will wander the lands of men in solitary waiting. Perhaps few are the years in which she will know full and perfect happiness compared to our elven life, but it will be a life of love, and the memory will suffice for her.”
“You have become wise, Galadriel. Where is the proud warrior maiden who defied Gil-galad and even the Valar themselves?”
Galadriel’s lips curved in an indulgent smile:
“Oh, foolish and vainglorious girl. I believe she has been forged by years and experiences.”
“Indeed, I believe so too.”
For a few minutes, the two Elves remained contemplating the horizon, each lost in their own thoughts, their fingers intertwined in silent conversation. The first evening star shone in the east, and the cold sea breeze made Galadriel shiver.
“My friend, do not linger in the evening shadows of a sorrowful old heart. Soon, I hear in the distance a melody: the two young ones from the Shire are singing one of their amusing hobbit songs. And what a wonder: if my ears do not deceive me, I recognize the voice of Mithrandir!”
Galadriel gathered up her long gown, dampened by salty droplets, and offered her arm to Elrond:
“I accept your counsel, but I would prefer the company of an old friend, should he agree to join me.”
Elrond bowed his head in a gracious nod, and his stern face softened into a smile. He took his friend's arm, and together they walked the white wooden planks of the deck towards the music and laughter.
writing_prompt: As the Elven ship sails toward the Blessed Land, Elrond and Galadriel reflect on the choices, losses, and memories left behind in Middle-earth—until the distant sound of hobbit songs and laughter stirs a bittersweet hope.

post_title: During a boat trip with the brothers of Dol Amroth, Éomer is confronted with an old superstition of the Mark. While Lothíriel, blissfully unaware, enjoys herself steering the sails, Éomer struggles to maintain his dignity amidst the teasing of the Amrothian brothers, who never miss a chance to poke fun at him.
comment:
Éomer sat uneasily on the edge of the cushioned bench in the small boat that the princes of Dol Amroth had convinced him to board. The vessel was a miniature replica of the grand swan ships typical of their fleet, offering every comfort despite its smaller size—softly padded seats, a canopy to shield from the sun, and even a tiny galley.
It was not the sailing itself that troubled him, though the King of the Mark was certainly unaccustomed to the boat’s sway and the feel of bare feet on salt-slicked wood. What truly furrowed Éomer’s brow was the figure standing at the prow. Lothíriel, laughing with her brother Erchirion as she helped manage the sails, was a vision of beauty and freedom. Barefoot, skirts hitched to ease her movements, and her hair tied hastily with rebellious strands whipping in the sea breeze, she was a sight both delightful and painfully distracting to Éomer. And yet, in his heart, there stirred a superstitious fear.
“Well, Éomer, what’s with that face?”
Amrothos called out as he plopped down beside him.
“You look as if the sea’s gotten the better of you.”
Erchirion chimed in, sitting across from him. Éomer ground his teeth.
“I am not seasick.”
“Then what is it? We didn’t invite you aboard to sulk in a corner, and we certainly didn’t leave one brooding bore behind only to find another onboard!”
Amrothos teased, flashing a grin at Erchirion, clearly referring to their elder brother Elphir, who had stayed behind to tend to his duties. Éomer merely shrugged, but the brothers were not easily deterred.
Erchirion laughed aloud, noticing where Éomer’s gaze had wandered.
“It seems our friend doesn’t quite approve of a certain presence on this ship, brother.”
Amrothos followed Éomer’s line of sight and snickered.
“Is that so?”
“I am only wondering if her behavior is fitting for her station,” Éomer replied dryly.
The brothers exchanged knowing looks, and Amrothos shrugged.
“You know how my sister is. She insisted on joining us…”
“…and we can deny her nothing,” Erchirion finished with a grin.
Éomer was about to retort when the boat lurched unexpectedly, nearly throwing them from their seats. Lothíriel let out a triumphant cheer as she righted the sail. She glanced back at Éomer with a mischievous smile, and he, raising a hand in greeting, returned to his brooding, staring out over the waves. Yet the princes of Dol Amroth were not done with him.
“Something still seems to trouble our Horse Lord,” Erchirion remarked with mock seriousness.
“Come now, Éomer, confess to your friends. Have we not shared glory, blood, and dust on the fields of battle?” Amrothos added with a laugh.
Éomer sighed, knowing they would give him no peace until he spoke.
“You are worse than washerwomen at the riverbank," he grumbled. "Very well. Since you won’t cease pestering me until I tell you, here it is.”
The brothers chuckled, awaiting his revelation.
“In my land, it is believed that having women aboard ships brings ill fortune and disaster. There, I’ve said it.”
He concluded with a scowl, daring them to mock him.
Amrothos and Erchirion struggled to contain their laughter until Amrothos finally burst out, “That’s the strangest thing I’ve ever heard!”
“Come now, friend,” Erchirion added, still chuckling. “Dol Amroth thrives under such superstitions, and our women are a common sight upon our ships.”
Éomer crossed his arms, frowning. He knew they wouldn’t let it go so easily. And indeed, his torment was not over, for Erchirion, struck by sudden inspiration, nudged his brother.
“Let’s call Lothíriel over—she can surely set our friend’s mind at ease.”
“An excellent idea, brother.”
Amrothos grinned. Éomer’s eyes widened in alarm, and he moved to rise and stop them, but another roll of the boat sent him crashing back onto the bench.
“For the love of Béma…” he muttered under his breath, cursing both himself and the moment he’d agreed to this accursed voyage!
writing_prompt: Éomer, unaccustomed to the sea and its strange customs, finds himself aboard a Dol Amroth ship with the lively and free-spirited Lothíriel, whose presence stirs both his heart and his superstitions. What happens when the princes of Dol Amroth decide to tease the King of Rohan about his unease?

post_title: After their first night as husband and wife, Éomer and Lothíriel reflect on their future and what “home” truly means.
comment:
Éomer stood by the window of the royal chamber, gazing out but not truly seeing the rooftops of Edoras below. The cool morning breeze brushed against his bare chest, raising the fine golden hairs upon his skin. Unbothered by the chill or the goosebumps it caused, he turned to look upon his bride. Lothíriel was still nestled in the soft bedding of their marriage bed, dark curls spilling over her peaceful face. Her breathing was deep and steady, a clear sign that she remained in the depths of slumber. Éomer’s eyes softened, his lips curving into a gentle smile. He cast his gaze back to the fortress-city his ancestors had built, as the first sounds of harnesses clinking reached his ears, mingling with the early calls of birds and the murmurs of soldiers and workers beginning their day.
A soft murmur from the bed furrowed the king’s brow, and he turned once more to Lothíriel. She had shifted, her golden arms draped across the white pillows, the sheet tangled around her waist. A corner of the thick blanket had slipped to the floor, revealing the chubby curve of her thigh. Éomer licked his lips, wondering if he had been too rough or too eager the night before. He had tried to be gentle, mindful of her inexperience, but despite his efforts to please her, he had found himself unable to resist the urge to sink deeply into the warmth of her womb, drinking of her honeyed lips like a man dying of thirst.
Lost in the memory, he did not hear the soft rustle of the sheets as a small, cool hand slipped into his own, large and warm.
“Couldn’t sleep, or is this the hour you rise? Perhaps I should begin your day, as befits my new role as wife?”
“Loth, no. You are queen now; you may return to your rest if you wish.”
Éomer brought her hand to his lips with a smile, pressing a chaste kiss to her fingertips. He gazed at her with eyes bright with desire. She was so beautiful, partially covered by the white sheet, glowing like the dawn veiled in mist. The sight stole his breath, but his brow furrowed for a moment.
“Are you… well? Was your rest sufficient?”
He feared to ask if she felt any discomfort, or if his passion had displeased her in any way. Lothíriel adjusted the sheet around her bare body, suddenly shy at the memory of the night. She bit her lower lip, trying to hide a small, satisfied smile.
“My sleep was more than… satisfactory, my lord.”
“Éomer. Only Éomer.”
“Only Éomer. I was very tired, perhaps you had something to do with that.”
They both smiled. Lothíriel turned toward the window, her profile framed against the dark wood of the walls, her gaze taking in the same landscape her husband had absently observed only moments before. From their high vantage point, they could see the green pastures dotted with white flowers, stretching endlessly toward the distant mountains. Just then, a gust of wind rippled across the grassy plains, making the white blossoms dance like foam on the waves.
“So, this is my new land,” Lothíriel murmured. “So different, so green.”
“And you will reign over its people and herds alongside me.”
Lothíriel did not answer, her gaze still fixed on the wind-swept fields.
“It looks like a sea, though so different from the one I used to watch from my windows in Dol Amroth. Yet no less vast, no less dangerous, and worthy of love and respect all the same.”
Éomer’s brows knit together, a thorn of worry pricking his heart.
“Do you long for home, Sea Princess?”
Lothíriel shook her head and placed her hand over Éomer’s chest. She smiled softly and replied,
“My home is here: wherever your heart is, there my dwelling shall be.”
Éomer felt his worries melt away, his features softening into a smile as tenderness filled his heart. He gathered Lothíriel into his arms, capturing her lips in a loving kiss.
writing_prompt: A sea princess, now queen of a landlocked kingdom, finds herself torn between the rolling waves of her past and the endless green fields of her future. How does she navigate her new life, her love, and the call of two worlds?

post_title: When Éomer loses track of the puppy his sister entrusted to him, he finds himself wandering frustrated through the gardens of the Citadel in Minas Tirith. But the furry little disaster leads him to a glade where he encounters a young princess who seems to have won the puppy's heart... and perhaps the heart of the King of the Mark as well.
comment:
The tall, blond man snorted through his nose, carelessly brushing aside the foliage in the small park of the Citadel of Minas Tirith, kicking at twigs and leaves that blocked his path. He muttered—no, more like growled—to himself:
"Where has that wretched beast gone? I swear, the moment I get my hands on it, I’ll wring its neck!"
He swore to himself then and there that he would never again do a favor for his sister. Better to hole up in the stables and tend horses for the rest of his days, something he was already attempting with little success. The sound of joyful barking drew him toward a small clearing. There, he immediately noticed the white puppy bouncing and barking gleefully around a figure crouched low to the ground. The figure was clearly of noble birth: her heavy, amaranth-colored skirt lay spread around her on the grass like the petals of a flower, making her seem like some woodland creature. Her dark curls framed her shoulders, hiding her face.
Éomer’s lips tugged up at the corners despite himself at the sight, wondering if perhaps he had stumbled upon one of Queen Arwen’s Elves.
Meanwhile, the puppy danced about her, a little cloud of pure happiness. A sarcastic puff of air escaped Éomer’s lips, and she lifted her face. Éomer nearly fell to his knees then and there; his heart raced madly, his palms dampened so quickly that he had to resist the urge to wipe them on his trousers. The sound of her laughter shattered the last shred of dignity the King of the Mark clung to, forcing him to clear his throat several times.
Lothíriel placed a hand over her chest in a small gesture of surprise.
"Oh! Is this little one yours? I hope you don’t mind that I’ve kept him entertained with a bit of play."
Her voice was sweet, and the slightest trace of a southern accent lingered beneath the well-spoken Westron she used. Éomer knew that his own accent, by contrast, was rather rough, and for a moment, he regretted not having taken more lessons when he had the chance. He scratched his beard and gruffly replied:
"Actually, he belongs to my sister."
"He is so sweet and utterly adorable, truly delightful!"
Lothíriel offered her hand, and Éomer rushed forward to help her up. Her grip was firm on his arm, and for a fleeting moment, he caught the faint scent of apples from her dark hair. With a wry smile, he remarked:
"It’s curious that you’d say that, given that he behaves more like a goblin from the mines."
In response, the puppy bared its tiny teeth in a growl. Lothíriel giggled and scrunched her nose in a mischievous little smirk.
"Perhaps he is sensitive to the stern ways of the valiant knight who watches over him."
For a moment, Éomer stiffened at the subtle rebuke, but the playful glint in Lothíriel’s eyes made him dissolve into laughter. Oh, if only he could subject
her
to the kind of care he had in mind!
He bowed his head in a slight nod as the puppy wagged its tail around their legs. Their eyes met in a conversation that required no words. But the faintly alarmed voice of a court lady interrupted the moment:
"Princess! It is time to return to your duties."
Éomer pressed his lips together in frustration. Lothíriel furrowed her brow in a small gesture of displeasure but widened her lips in a smile.
"As you heard, my lord, my duties call me."
She bent to give the puppy one last affectionate pat, then made her way toward her companion, giggling and whispering as she went. Éomer stood frozen in the center of the glade, cursing himself for not having had the presence of mind to ask for a meeting—or at least her name. Absently, he picked up the trembling, growling puppy and ran his fingers through its curls. In a low voice, he muttered:
"Perhaps I won’t throw you to the sharp fangs of some passing orc after all."
In response, the dog barked and sank its tiny teeth into his hand. With a yelp, Éomer dropped it, and the creature seized the opportunity to flee, forcing him to chase after it, shouting curses all the while.
writing_prompt: While chasing after a mischievous puppy in the gardens of Minas Tirith, Éomer stumbles upon a mysterious noblewoman whose laughter and charm leave him utterly spellbound—but duty calls her away before he can even learn her name.

post_title: Faramir and Éowyn share a romantic breakfast in the gardens of the Houses of Healing. Amidst laughter and confidences, Faramir recounts a humorous story about Éomer, leading Éowyn to reflect on her brother and the possibility of new love for him.
comment:
It had become a cherished habit for the Prince of Ithilien and his future bride to take their morning meal together in the herb gardens of the Houses of Healing in the Citadel of Minas Tirith. A table was always set for them in the aromatic garden, a place dear to them both, for it had witnessed the blossoming of their love and many moments of intimate joy. To them, it seemed a foretaste of their wedded life, and they indulged in it with the greatest delight.
Éowyn was pouring strong Rohirric coffee into their cups, a taste Faramir had acquired, though he could only tolerate it if it was drowned in milk and sugar. This peculiarity never failed to exasperate his future spouse, who would teasingly chide him with playful resignation. As he buttered a slice of soft milk bread from the King's bakery, Faramir began:
“My dear Éowyn, I heard an interesting story this morning.”
He offered the bread to the lady, who raised an inquisitive eyebrow.
“What story? Are we speaking of an intriguing epic of high sovereign deliberations or the usual courtly gossip? You know well I adore the former and despise the latter.”
Éowyn concluded, taking a bite of the bread. Her eyes sparkled with mischievous mirth, and her golden hair shone like molten honey in the sun. Faramir leaned forward, once again admiring the beauty of his betrothed, and brushed a rebellious black lock from his forehead.
“As to that, it is for you to judge, fair lady.”
“Oh, enough with riddles!”
He leaned back in his chair, smiling, for he always enjoyed teasing the fiery nature of the White Lady. Her blue eyes flashed as she menacingly wielded the small knife, stabbing a particularly plump herring. Faramir showed the palms of his hands, exclaiming:
“Never would I seek to arouse the ire of my sweet lady.”
Éowyn scoffed mockingly and let the unfortunate fish fall onto the buttered bread. Meanwhile, Faramir had picked a particularly juicy strawberry from the bowl before him and offered it to his future bride as a peace offering. She closed her eyes, her lips parting to savor the plump fruit with delight, and it was in moments like these that Faramir longed all the more for their wedding day to come swiftly. Éowyn’s voice distracted him from his less-than-virtuous musings.
“So, this story. Do not make me beg, my lord.”
“Oh, I shall leave your supplications for our wedding night!”
A forcefully thrown napkin stifled his laughter. As he composed himself, the stern look in Éowyn’s eyes urged him to speak.
“Well, your brother Éomer and Lothíriel were seen in a stable.”
“Oh, no! And what were they doing?”
“It seems they were grooming a horse. Or rather, Éomer was teaching my cousin to groom a horse.”
Faramir replied with an amused smile. Éowyn's eyes widened, and she burst into laughter.
“Typical of my brother: courting a girl in a stable! He couldn't be more Rohirric if he tried.”
Faramir took her hand as she shook her head and said:
“Not all use sweet words and gift heirlooms. Yet, it seems to be working.”
Éowyn's expression softened at the memory of the evening when Faramir had draped her mother's precious cloak over her shoulders, giving her his heart along with it. Suddenly, her expression turned into a frown.
“I know that wrinkle between your eyes, what troubles my lady?”
“I wonder if Lothíriel will be able to handle him. Éomer is a good man, but he is impetuous and can be stubborn.”
Faramir held Éowyn’s hand between his and bent to place a small kiss on it.
“I know someone like him, a fearless and passionate maiden. She too is of Rohan... and yet, she fell into my arms like a ripe, sweet fruit.”
Éowyn, despite herself, smiled.
“Braggart! If Lothíriel is made of the same stuff as her cousin, she will surely enchant him with her melodious words.”
“She will: Lothíriel has a keen mind and a resolute character, though her youthful features might suggest otherwise.”
Éowyn looked at him with affection and felt confident that her brother had found a companion capable of standing up to him.
“So, we shall have another wedding to organize.”
“I prefer to organize ours. Or, better yet, I prefer to think of when I shall have my bride all to myself.”
Éowyn chuckled, a sound new to her lips, and covered her mouth with her hands. Faramir, smiling, gently lowered them and pressed a loving kiss on her lips.

post_title: Éomer feels overwhelmed by social pressures and is concerned about the whispers circulating among the Gondorian courtiers regarding his status as a king and his courtship of Princess Lothiriel. His sister Éowyn seeks to reassure him.
comment:
Éomer could perceive them, the whispers behind the affable smiles of the Gondorian courtiers: here is the barbarian king, here he is, with his rough manners courting our princesses, he and his uncouth horsemen tarnishing the white roads of the Kingdom, preying upon innocent maidens. And their women, Valar!, call them shield maidens, yet they can fight and ride bare-legged! So incessant were the murmurings and whispers of scandalized women and disgruntled fathers. Éomer would have liked to laugh at those foolish rumors since he had witnessed for himself how the timid Gondorian maidens nearly threw themselves into the tents of his riders, and conversely, how he had had to growl more than once at some lewd glances thrown by the Gondorian nobles at the daughters of the Mark. He could have ignored and laughed at those nonsensical tales, but his temper boiled at the thought that the honor of his people was less than immaculate in the eyes of their new allies. Éomer stood observing the landscape from the palace balconies, the camp of the Éorlingas at the gates of Minas Tirith resounding with the neighing of horses, distant songs and shouts, and the rhythmic clinking of blacksmiths at work on their anvils. The knuckles of his hand were white as the stone he gripped, his face marked by hard, thin lines that somewhat marred his fair, noble beauty. He raised his eyes to the snow-capped peaks of the distant mountains, seeking in their placid, immaculate beauty some relief from the troubling thoughts that beset him.
“There you are: I was looking for you, brother.”
The voice of Éowyn brought him back to the present. The White Lady approached him and observed the camp for a moment. In a casual tone, she playfully teased him:
“It seems that the King of Rohan is hiding.”
Éomer straightened, his mouth a thin line, his eyes tempestuous:
“I am not hiding! I was merely seeking a moment of peace from the incessant chatter of these Gondorian
bædling
(eunuchs)!”
Éowyn chuckled, raising her hands:
“I come in peace! And let them say what they will. They are but gossip, mediocre talk from the envious.”
Éomer clenched his fists, frustrated. He shook his head, the boiling anger simmering just beneath the surface:
“They speak as if we are barbarians, as if we are unworthy of their company or their daughters. It infuriates me.”
She tilted her head and rested her index finger on her chin in thought:
“Is it because of Lothiriel? Do you fear she may give credence to the whispers? She is young, yet well-tempered by the trials of war and the harsh art of command.”
Éomer turned again towards the mountains, avoiding his sister's gaze, a veil of uncertainty in his voice:
“She looks at me with little less than disdain, fear clouds her eyes. I can see it.”
“Perhaps what you see reflected in her eyes is the fear of your own heart. I see neither disdain nor fear in her.”
Éomer pressed his lips together, not entirely convinced. When Aragorn had proposed forging alliances with the southern kingdoms, he had not imagined that among the commitments would be the need to take as his bride a spoiled little princess, the daughter of his dear friend from Imrahil of Dol Amroth. Yet, Lothiriel had struck him with her exquisite beauty and sharp wit. Éomer turned and leaned against the stone balustrade, crossing his arms:
“You have grown wise, sister. Nonetheless, Lothiriel is little more than a child; I am not certain she will be able to discern the truth from the slanders.”
“Give her the credit she deserves! Not all Gondorians are of short wit and dull spirit, as my future husband well demonstrates!”
Éowyn replied passionately, defending her newly acquired family. Éomer softened, smoothing his brow, and smiled:
“Love does you good, sister.”
Éowyn bowed her head as a soft rose hue spread across her pale cheeks, a self-satisfied smile stretching her lips. Then, lifting her gaze, she asked with a mix of sweetness and challenge:
“Are we happy, Éomer?”
The question caught him by surprise, and for a moment he remained silent, studying his sister's face and reflecting upon himself. Then, with a slight curl of his lips:
“We shall be, I promise you. There is a light in your eyes that I have not seen in far too long, and I think the credit belongs to the Steward.”
“Indeed, it is so.”
Murmured Éowyn with an irrepressible smile. Éomer furrowed his brow and left the parapet he had leaned against:
“But if I find that handsome Gondorian has laid hands upon you, by the balls of Bema, I…”
“Precisely for this I sought you! We must decide which ribbons you will wear for our handfasting ceremony.”

post_title: Amidst the vibrant festivities of a grand banquet, Éomer and Lothíriel find themselves drawn to each other, sharing stolen glances and subtle exchanges. As they navigate their growing feelings, the backdrop of celebration reveals the challenges and expectations of their noble standings.
comment:
On the terraces of the Citadel, a gentle breeze wafted through the air. Low tables, large cushions, and thick carpets were arranged with care, the linen cloths embroidered with the symbols of Rohan, and the white muslin of Gondor reflected the sunlight. Upon them lay silver platters filled with simple yet delightful fare: savory pies, salads of fresh fruit, slices of seed bread dipped in Dol Amroth's oil, portions of roast with a crisp crust, and morsels of spiced meat. Carafes of refreshing juices, white and red wine, sweet ratafia, and sparkling mead glimmered in the sun. Some elvish silk drapes had been stretched between decorated poles adorned with ribbons and red vine tendrils to provide shade for the guests.
Not long before, the Citadel had been animated by a grand parade of Gondorian warriors, their silver armor shining beneath the warm autumn sun, and their long pikes reflecting rays of light. The Rohirrim knights had demonstrated their valor in a jousting exhibition: their powerful and agile steeds moved with perfect precision and grace, while the riders showcased their legendary equestrian mastery. Following this, the elegant knights of Dol Amroth glided onto the scene, their capes billowing like sails, as some sailors from the maritime realm displayed their skill in knot and rigging games, throwing ceremonial ropes and nets into the air, amidst the admiring applause of the spectators.
Throughout the ceremony, Éomer had maintained a composed expression, befitting a King of the Mark. Yet, every so often, his gaze inevitably slipped towards the beautiful daughter of Imrahil. Her attire, rich as befitted a princess, was of refined simplicity. The silver and blue cloak fluttered lightly in the breeze, occasionally revealing the amber skin of her shoulders, and, Bema help him, a generous portion of her collarbones. But it was Lothíriel's face that truly captured Éomer's attention: her bright eyes and full lips seemed to hide a secret smile.
Lothíriel, for her part, did not fail to notice the fleeting yet fervent glances the King of Rohan cast her way. She felt flattered, intrigued by the contrast between his imposing presence and the apparent shyness that shone through his gestures. Gracefully, she offered him a few subtle smiles, hoping that Éomer would grasp the message hidden behind her composure. He was no Boromir, of course, and she would never forget him. However, there was something about this warrior king that reminded her of him, and she was ready to give him a chance. Her father had hinted at a promise, and Lothíriel, fully aware of the role she was meant to play from birth, intended to honor it to the best of her ability. If the sovereign she was destined for was to be that proud barbarian king, well, she would not be intimidated.
Later, after the horses and their riders had been refreshed, the foot soldiers and sailors found respite, and every noble of the court had settled at the long, informal low tables prepared for the feast, Éomer was called loudly by the Dol Amrothian brothers with whom he had forged a sincere friendship as well as a steadfast military alliance. With a nod of his head, King Elassar gave his consent, and so Éomer found himself seated right next to Lothíriel. Perhaps it was mere coincidence, or perhaps not: Imrahil's knowing smile did not entirely escape him, making him suspect that the princess's family had orchestrated the meeting. In any case, he preferred it this way: he felt more at ease among the jovial and witty knights of Dol Amroth than among the pompous and haughty nobles of Gondor. Not to mention, it had the undeniable advantage of sitting next to the princess. It mattered little if the prince—her father—had had a hand in it. He continued to watch her as she laughed and conversed animatedly with her brothers, revealing more of her sharp wit and undeniable beauty. Though distracted by the charms of his neighbor, Éomer still managed, albeit with some difficulty, to respond to the jests of his newfound friends. At one point, one of the guests offered Lothíriel another glass of ratafia, and before she could accept, Éomer interjected in a measured tone:
“Surely the princess would prefer a glass of fresh spring water.”
Lothíriel was taken aback and, without allowing the others to hear, whispered with a tone betraying her displeasure:
“I thank my lord for his concern, but you are not a relative to whom I must account for my libations.”
“True, I am not your kin."
A “
not yet
” lingered between them for a moment, an unspoken tension that vibrated the air with unexpressed possibilities. Realizing he had overstepped, Éomer made an embarrassed grimace and replied:
"Please forgive my intrusion.”
It was for this reason that Éomer, to ease the atmosphere, offered her a delicacy typical of Rohan: a buttery apple turnover.
“I recall you particularly enjoyed it when you had the chance to taste it.”
Lothíriel immediately understood that it was a gesture of peace, a way to apologize and to convey that his attentions were sincere. She took a bite, and when Éomer saw her tongue licking the filling from her lips, he felt a shiver run down his spine. He struggled to maintain his composure, but within him, he was nearly going mad: may Bema help him, that girl would be his undoing!
writing_prompt: At a grand feast celebrating the alliance between Rohan and Gondor, Éomer, the proud King of the Mark, finds himself seated beside Lothíriel, the sharp-witted and captivating daughter of Imrahil. Amidst subtle glances, unspoken tensions, and a buttery apple turnover, their fates begin to intertwine—will duty or desire prevail?

post_title: It is night in Bag End, and the Gamgee house is enveloped in an apparent quiet. While the silence of the Shire reigns outside, within the home of Sam and Rosie, a vibrant atmosphere anticipates an event that will transform the tranquility of the night into a memorable moment for the hobbit family.
comment:
The stars of evening already shone high in the sky above Bag End, the late roses and daffodils swayed in the gentle yet brisk breeze of early autumn, while the crickets lingered to sing their last summer songs and the frogs answered with their languid symphony. The hobbits slept peacefully in their comfortable beds, comforted by the crackling fires and the peace that had reigned in the Shire for many long years. Even the mayor's house was wrapped in silence and peace, save for a single light that shone in waiting. The lady of the house sat in the quiet, mending the small clothes that grew steadily into a larger pile in the basket at her feet. Her children lay asleep here and there, curled up on the sofa, nestled before the fire, clutching the large cushions adorned with gold and green designs of Rohan. Wooden blocks, rag dolls with pointed ears, toy horses, soldiers in Gondorian armor, and other toys were scattered on the floor, as if they had fallen into an enchanted sleep where their little owners had left them. Rosie shook her golden curls with a sigh; she had not been able to send the little ones to bed before their father's return. So, she had resigned herself to letting them stay up until their tired limbs, weary from a long day of games, races, and soon-settled squabbles, were overcome by the heavy blanket of sleep. She brought both hands to caress her belly, swollen with new life, and smiled at the baby's movement within. Her Sam often told her she was too indulgent with the children:
"They will say that the mayor of Bag End has raised a brood of wild goblins."
He would often chide, but Rosie would shrug with a smile and quietly respond:
"Let them say so, dear Sam. Let them say so."
And when he continued to fret over the children’s behavior, she would sternly retort:
"Have the respectable citizens of Hobbiton traveled to Mordor and helped bear the Ring through those dreadful lands even to its destruction? Have the honorable hobbits of Bag End who might offer reproach faced the unspeakable perils to which their mayor has been exposed? It is for these deeds that they place so much trust in you, not for how your children are raised."
Rosie, with her tireless love for the family, showed a protective fierceness akin to that of a weasel, and like the weasel, she stood with determination and agility, ready to defend every member of her family with strength and cunning. Now a stocky figure, cloaked in a heavy dark mantle, travel bags, and a staff, made its way up the path to the house. His shoulders were bowed toward the ground as if bearing the weight of days and roads traveled, but his step was merry, as much as his weariness allowed, as if his furry feet themselves were impatient to reach home. It was Frodo's ears, the second-born, that first caught the sound of the latch lifting, his little eyes snapped open as the young hobbit exclaimed:
"Papa! Papa is back!"
Immediately, his siblings woke to welcome the much-anticipated guest, while their mother tried to quell their excitement:
"Gently, Frodo! Hamfast, don't bump into your brothers! No, Merry, your father can't listen to your new song right now! Pippin, don't wave that wooden sword around, you might poke someone's eye out! Elanor, Rose, please help me up. Ooh. Come, Goldilocks, give me your hand."
When Rosie finally managed to rise from her chair, Sam was already surrounded by the brood of little hobbits clamoring for his attention. He smiled, bestowing caresses, kisses, and words of praise. Rosie held onto the doorframe, observing the scene with tender eyes, but nothing was more loving than the look her husband gave her when their eyes met over the heads of their children.
It took a few more frenzied moments before the little hobbits could be persuaded to go to bed, too excited by Sam's return and unsettled by their interrupted first sleep, but finally the house was blessed by a quiet silence, enveloped in a darkness no longer filled with unknown terrors but rich with peace, like a cloak wrapping it in the warmth and tranquility of a safe haven. A single light still shone, the fire crackled cheerfully in the kitchen, casting a soft glow on the furniture and the time-worn wooden floor. Sam sat at the table, his feet still muddy, and a myriad of tiny lines around his blue eyes spoke of his weariness. He covered his open mouth with one hand in a yawn. Rosie bustled about him, nimble and quick despite her pregnancy. She asked:
"Have you eaten?"
"A morsel on the road, but I wouldn't refuse a bowl of that good mushroom soup whose scent I caught from the start of the path."
Rosie chuckled as she placed a steaming bowl of soup in front of her husband, and Sam eagerly plunged his spoon into the soup, stuffing a large spoonful into his mouth. Rosie didn’t have time to warn him before he withdrew with a groan, pressing both hands to his lips. With an indulgent smile, Rosie poured him a generous serving of wine:
"I was going to tell you to blow on it or you’d burn yourself!"
Sam mumbled something as he reached for the glass, taking a large gulp of wine to soothe his tongue. Rosie approached him lightly, an affectionate look passing between them as she sat at the table. She handed him a thick slice of toasted bread to dip in the soup. They spoke of their respective days in hushed voices so as not to wake the children, enjoying that moment of calm.
"It has been a long day," said Sam, lifting his tired but satisfied gaze. Rosie placed a hand on his shoulder:
"You brought the warmth of your presence into this cold night. We missed you so much..."
Sam smiled, caressing his wife's hand in return:
"Let's say the little ones made that abundantly clear! And now that the house is warm, I can enjoy a bit of peace with my lady."
They rose together, and Rosie led him to the bath, helping him undress with loving gestures, gently washing away the weariness and grime of the journey along with the foam. Sam thanked her with a tender kiss as they slipped beneath the covers of their bed. The fire burned in the hearth, no less warm than the fires of their hearts. Sam took Rosie’s hand in his, and she rested her head on his shoulder, their gazes intertwined as if it were the strongest bond at that moment, and indeed, it was so.
writing_prompt: On a quiet autumn evening in the Shire, Rosie waits for Sam's return from a long journey, their home filled with the warmth of children’s laughter and the promise of new life. What stories does Sam bring back to share, and how does the love of family shape their peaceful night?

post_title: How Éomer and Firefoot became companions.
comment:
Éomer groaned as he lowered his bruised limbs into the icy water of the tub outside the barracks. He was one of the most promising riders of his generation, or so Commander Elfhelm had told his cousin Théodred. Éomer hadn’t meant to eavesdrop, but nonetheless, his young chest had swelled with pride upon hearing it.
But now the bruises covering much of his body painfully reminded him that he had yet to tame a horse of his own. The water was cold, but his mind burned with frustration. He had failed to tame Firefoot, and the defeat weighed more heavily than the blows he had taken.
A group of young riders passed by, laughing and joking, their faces already alight with the prospect of an evening in the tavern. One of them, a tousle-haired youth, glanced his way and laughed.
“I can’t wait to bury my face between Beylith’s sweet breasts!”
The others joined in his laughter, urging their companion on as he gestured wildly, describing the curves of the young woman.
“They say they are softer than the blankets of our commander!”
“Oh, speaking of the commander’s blankets, our Éomer knows something about that!” added another companion with a lewd grin.
“Why don’t you go suck Oromë’s cock instead?” Éomer retorted darkly. Had he not been naked, he would have risen to teach those fools a lesson—though it had happened before. But now, his body was too sore to incite a brawl.
“Come on, lads! Our Éomer, after all his tumbles, must have a sore bum!”
As the group moved away, Éomer splashed the water with a hand, sending droplets flying all around. Let them go and have their fun; stallions were not tamed by idle chatter, and he would show them that. His thoughts returned to Théodred and what his cousin had said. He didn’t want to disappoint him. He had been chosen for something greater, Éomer knew that. Yet, he couldn’t shake the feeling of failure. When they had lost their parents, Uncle Théoden had taken him and his little sister in with open arms, raising them as his own children, and Théodred had taken an immediate liking to them. Éomer felt he owed much to them both, and it was his duty to make them proud.
That’s why he had eagerly accepted the offer to join one of the eoreds of the Mark and had worked hard during training. Yet, when he first laid eyes on that horse, he had felt an immediate connection with the beast. Firefoot’s powerful, taut muscles, his brooding gaze, and his temper, which seemed ready to send flames flaring from his nostrils at any moment, had discouraged more than one rider. In truth, even the most skilled horsemen had failed to tame him. And that was exactly what Éomer wanted.
For the past several days and that very afternoon, Éomer had attempted to tame him, but Firefoot had been just as determined not to cooperate. That afternoon, Éomer had spent hours throwing the reins over Firefoot and trying to ride him bareback, only to be bucked off again and again—once, twice, five, fifteen times. A decent circle of onlookers had gathered around the training ring, laughing, cheering, though whether for him or the horse, Éomer wasn’t sure.
Even Commander Elfhelm and Théodred had paused to watch. At first, Éomer hadn’t noticed, so focused was he on his efforts, drenched in sweat and thoroughly disheveled.
“How long has this been going on? Perhaps you’d have better luck with a pony, boy!” Théodred teased good-naturedly. Éomer grimaced, attempting once again to stay on the unruly horse. Elfhelm chuckled.
“If I didn’t know for sure that he was a horse, I might mistake them both for two mules. I can’t tell which of them is more stubborn.”
But there was fondness in the commander’s tone.
Now, Éomer rested his head on the edge of the tub with a sigh. The water had warmed a little, and the bruises hurt less, certainly less than his wounded pride. He looked up at the stars; Borgil glowed red beside the constellation Remmirath, the small blue flowers Varda had set in the skies before the beginning of time. Éomer knew little of cosmology, but he cherished the legends of his ancestors, and the red fury of Borgil reminded him of the proud Túrin, Dragon-slayer. The air around him turned cold, and the boy shivered.
He heard a soft clatter of hooves and a gentle whinny coming from the stables nearby. The astute grumble of his empty stomach shook him from his melancholic stupor. An idea sparked in Éomer’s mind: if that horse was anything like him, as everyone joked, then there was one thing he surely couldn’t resist.
After hurriedly drying off and pulling on his tunic and boots, Éomer crept into the kitchens, still thick with the scent of roasted meat and warm bread. He snatched half a honey loaf and soaked it in the savory, rich gravy left from the roast. Quickly, he darted to the barrels and crates filled with fruits and vegetables in the pantry and grabbed a few carrots and an apple. Slipping through the shadows of the barracks, he stealthily approached Firefoot’s stall with his treasures hidden under his cloak.
The horse eyed him darkly, blowing warm air from his nostrils. When Éomer attempted to stroke the soft hair of his nose, Firefoot kicked out, striking the wooden stall with a thundering thud.
“Shh, easy there. Easy. I’ve brought you something.”
He held a large, juicy carrot under the horse’s nose, letting Firefoot catch the scent of his fingers mingling with the treat. For a moment, the horse didn’t move, only twitching his ears and flaring his nostrils.
If Firefoot was stubborn, Éomer was no less so. They stood locked in a battle of wills for what felt like an eternity. At last, Éomer’s patience was rewarded. Slowly, and with a hint of wariness, Firefoot grasped the carrot with his teeth.
“Good lad. My fine steed. We’ll be friends, you and I, won’t we? Together, we’ll do great things, win honor and glory.”
As the horse crunched through the unusual offering, Éomer rubbed the dark, velvety coat between his ears, showering him with praises and soft words.
It took more than two carrots, however, to win over the moody horse. Days of patient dedication, furtive nighttime visits to the stables, bruises, and gentle strokes were needed. But at last, Firefoot began to tolerate his presence. Slowly, through praise, bruises, caresses, and rewards, Éomer earned his trust.
For a few weeks, it seemed as though Éomer had given up on taming the brooding stallion, but that morning, under the curious and watchful eyes of Théodred and the commander, Éomer made his long-prepared display. He leapt onto Firefoot’s back, who bucked and tossed his head, but Éomer’s hands held the reins firmly. Before the astonished gaze of his comrades-in-arms, the young rider spurred Firefoot into a gallop, and with a mighty leap, they soared over the fence—right over the commander’s head. A chorus of cheers greeted his feat, and when Éomer wheeled the horse around and returned, he saw a newfound respect in his cousin’s eyes.
writing_prompt: A young Éomer, determined to prove himself, sets out to tame the most unruly and untamable horse in the stables—a fiery stallion named Firefoot. But will his stubbornness and ingenuity be enough to win the trust of the proud beast?

post_title: During the summer in Thiten Hûb, Lothíriel faces the frustrations of growing up wanting to join her siblings and cousins in their adventures and secretly hoping for a special moment with Boromir.
comment:
Thiten Hûb began as a small fishing village, then became a charming trading port, and finally transformed into a delightful and exclusive holiday resort. Over the years, even the princes of Dol Amroth found refuge in this enchanting place with their families. It was situated in a small bay, well protected from stormy winds and waves that could erode its shores, as well as from the incursions of the pirates of Umbar. A villa of rough white stone, called Bâr Láranen, stood almost perched over the sea. Pink and violet bougainvillea climbed along its walls, and a row of olive trees, myrtles, and lemons surrounded and concealed it from view. A staircase carved into the rock led down to the small private cove, where a dock was built, and the princes' boats were always moored. These said princes, all young men between eighteen and twenty-five years of age, dressed in cool raw linen tunics and trousers rolled up to their ankles, were busy joking amongst themselves. They threw jests and colorful skeins of thread at each other and splashed water with their bare feet. Their laughter rose high into the light turquoise sky, rivaling the cries of the seagulls.
Not far away, sitting with a discontented expression and her chin resting on her hand, Lothíriel watched them with pouting lips. This particular year she felt more isolated than ever: during the winter she had given her first tribute as a woman and now could no longer participate in the rambunctious activities she loved to do with her brothers and cousins. She still remembered when just the year before, she could lift her skirts and walk barefoot around one of the boats while Elphir called her:
"Come, Looloo, help us prepare the nets!"
"Alright, but I would like to come with you!"
Erchirion had smiled and tousled her hair:
"You're too little for these things. Maybe next time."
She had turned her face away, annoyed, and had sighed in despair:
"Always next time..."
Meanwhile, the three brothers had boarded the boat, and as they moved away on the sparkling water, Amrothos had shouted back to her, laughing:
"Don't worry, Looloo. I'll teach you to fish next time. I promise!"
But now that she was old enough to follow her brothers, that same condition prevented her from joining them. While the court at Bâr Láranen was small and life more relaxed, Lothíriel found herself facing the new restrictions imposed by her transition to adulthood, making her even more annoyed and frustrated.
"Lothíriel, straighten those shoulders and wear your hat."
The stern but gentle voice of her aunt Ivrinel cut through the air, her authoritative commands ringing clearly. Lothíriel immediately straightened up, but in a tiny act of rebellion refused to wear the hat, letting the sun's glare hide her impending tears. She dearly loved her aunt, who had tried to be a guardian and affectionate companion since her mother's death, but she was not yet ready to yield to the impositions of her new condition.
Bored, she sat on the small woven straw chair and watched her aunt placidly weaving cotton thread. Amrothos noticed his sister's gaze and approached her quietly:
"Hey, Looloo, you could make yourself useful and learn as well: then you could weave our nets!"
Lothíriel jumped and replied sharply:
"Don't call me that."
She tried to maintain her composure, and even though she adored her childhood nickname, it made her feel small and vulnerable. But Erchirion gave a complicit chuckle and supported his brother:
"And maybe you could wipe that gloomy expression off your face: you're making the sky darken!"
"Ah, leave it be, Erchirion," Amrothos intervened, "She's just upset because she can't play like a child anymore."
She glanced at her elder brother Elphir, who ignored her completely, focused on the fishing gear, making her feel even more invisible and isolated.
As every summer, the older cousins from Minas Tirith used to spend a few weeks at Thiten Hûb as guests of their uncle, to rest from the exertions of academic studies and military training. Mostly, to escape the atmosphere of sadness and the suffocating pressure always present in the Steward's house.
Even Faramir had approached her and smiled with an expression of pity in his eyes. This hurt her more than anything, but she stoically pressed her lips together. Faramir said gently:
"Don't fret too much, nethig: we will catch a fish for you. The fattest and tenderest, and we will roast it tonight with the most fragrant herbs in your honor."
"It's not the same."
She replied sullenly. He shrugged, being used to sharp responses and brusque manners since childhood. Even now, away from the pressure of Minas Tirith, Faramir maintained that patient calm he had learned as a child. He pulled back his hair and, with a little smile, went to confer with Elphir. Lothíriel immediately regretted the rudeness she had shown to Faramir, hunched back over her chair, and bit her lip. At that moment, Boromir turned towards her, haloed by the sun's reflection. His long black hair waved in the breeze, and to her eyes, he appeared as one of those legendary heroes of ancient times: Beren or Tuor or even Elendil, whom she used to sigh over during her evening readings. Boromir, in turn, approached the young girl with an enchanting smile, and she immediately straightened up and tucked a dark curl behind her ear. If Faramir, with his sweetness and patience, was close to her heart as a brother, Boromir, with his charisma and imposing presence, represented everything she imagined in a hero. When he smiled at her, her heart began to beat faster, and Lothíriel felt nervous and happy. For some time now, thinking about her cousin caused a sort of stir that made her agitated and euphoric at the same time, as if she had drunk a few drops too many of the sweet rose wine that Aunt Ivrinel hid in her dresser. Boromir addressed her playfully:
"So, little one, why don't you come fishing with us anymore?"
Lothíriel squirmed in her chair as she felt the heat rise to her cheeks:
"It's just... that... I can't anymore."
She stammered, trying not to reveal too much. She was terribly embarrassed by her secret, yet she felt the need to appear mature and worthy in front of him, though somewhat intimidated by his presence. A flash of understanding crossed Boromir's blue eyes, so he crouched beside her and said in a warm, reassuring voice:
"Don't worry, Lothíriel, we will find something fun to do together."
Being called by her full name made her feel special and important. She couldn't suppress a flirtatious smile as she asked:
"Really?"
"Yes, really. Gweston!"
He replied with a warm, enveloping laugh, placing a hand on his heart. Then he stood up and gave her a gentle pat on the head before joining the other boys. Lothíriel watched him go, feeling the spot where he had touched her sizzle, her heart still in turmoil. She hoped he would keep his promise, and her lips curled into a satisfied smile.
"Lothíriel, come help me with this thread."
The firm but gentle voice of her aunt called her back to reality. Indeed, Ivrinel's attentive eyes had not missed the sighs and yearnings of her niece. Lothíriel sighed slightly but obediently approached her aunt. As she walked over, she cast one last glance at the boys on the boat sailing away on the shimmering sea. With a sigh, she began to work alongside Ivrinel, but her mind kept returning to that smile and that promise. She vowed that one day she would find a way to spend time alone with Boromir, and that thought filled her heart with a sweet and eager anticipation.
writing_prompt: In a sunlit coastal villa surrounded by olive trees and bougainvillea, young Lothíriel struggles with the newfound restrictions of adulthood, yearning to join her brothers and cousins in their carefree adventures. When her charismatic cousin Boromir promises to find something fun for them to do together, her heart stirs with hope and a secret longing—what will she do to make that moment a reality?

Sunlight filtered into Éowyn’s bedchamber, casting gentle spirals of dust in the air. Naive had just drawn back the curtains, letting the morning light flood the room. The faithful handmaiden moved quietly, careful not to disturb her lady. After arranging the pillows, she curtsied and made her way to the door to fetch the breakfast tray. On the threshold, she met Faramir, who smiled at her kindly.
“Go on, Naive. I will take it from here.”
He spoke with his usual calm and reassuring voice. Naive cast one last glance at her lady to ensure she was awake and then curtsied again, leaving the room. Faramir approached the bed quietly, his gaze immediately settling on Éowyn. She was still lying amidst the bedclothes, her hair disheveled, though already more animated than in recent days. Despite her weariness, a renewed light shone in her eyes, and her cheeks no longer looked so pale. She greeted him with a shy smile.
“You shouldn’t be here. I’m hardly presentable.”
Faramir sat at the edge of the bed and took her hand.
“And where do you think I’ve been while you were unwell, my love? Not even Naive could keep me away.”
“Foolish husband. You look just as worn, with shadows under your eyes.”
Faramir shook his head as if to brush off such concerns.
“Do you feel up to eating something? Here, drink this; it’s warm.”
He offered her a steaming cup of chamomile and buttered a small scone. Éowyn accepted the tea eagerly but shook her head when he moved to feed her, though she brushed her hand against his jaw in thanks.
“Would you call for Naive, please? I need a bath after this long illness.”
Éowyn’s attempt to rise from the pillows betrayed her lingering weakness. Faramir, who had remained by her side, watched her with a gentle yet resolute expression.
“I’ve given Naive the morning off. She, too, worked tirelessly to tend to you.”
Éowyn huffed, crossing her arms, though her hands quickly fell back into her lap, as if her weariness prevented her from holding them up for long.
“But I need a bath! Perhaps Nestriell or Reanna could…”
Her voice sounded impatient, yet carried an undertone of fatigue. Faramir laughed softly and rose, moving toward the hearth, where a fire crackled softly.
“I will attend to it. I’ve already had plenty of hot water brought up and the fire stoked.”
Returning to her side, he stopped a mere step away, his tone calm yet resolute.
“You’re under no obligation. Perhaps you should not even see me in such a state,” murmured Éowyn, averting her gaze, her cheeks tinged with a faint blush. Faramir leaned down, taking her hand and pressing a gentle kiss to her fingers.
“But I wish to. And do you not?”
His words were a soft whisper, and his eyes met Éowyn’s, which, for a moment, glistened with a rare brightness, freed from their burden of shame. Gently, he helped her rise from the bed, slipping soft lapin slippers onto her feet and guiding her to the adjacent bath. Like the rest of Emyn Arnen’s castle, it was crafted from pale stone, lit by grand arched windows draped in heavy curtains. Éowyn missed the warmth of Meduseld’s wooden walls and floors, where one could walk barefoot without a chill. A merry fire crackled in the hearth, and soft white rugs surrounded the large tub. Before the fire, a few metal buckets were steaming, and Faramir poured the hot water into the tub, adding a few drops of peony-scented oil. With a small sigh, Éowyn allowed herself to be led toward the tub. Though she longed to shake off the remnants of illness, the idea of Faramir seeing her in such a state weighed heavily upon her. Yet his hand, so strong and certain in hers, brought comfort, though… there was still a small knot of shame she couldn’t quite untangle.
“I must be dreadful: my hair is all matted, and I must smell—”
She made a face, but Faramir gave no sign of hearing her complaint, guiding her carefully into the warm water. Éowyn couldn’t help a small sigh of relief.
“Where would you like to begin?”
“My hair.”
Faramir’s lips lifted into a slight smile, and he lathered soap in his hands. With gentle strokes, he worked the suds through her flaxen hair, untangling it carefully. He relished the feel of her hair in his hands, the weight of it, its familiar silken strands. Once her hair was thoroughly lathered, he began massaging her scalp in slow circles with his fingertips. Éowyn sighed languidly, her eyes closing as she relaxed into the soothing rhythm, shifting subtly in the water, causing soft ripples. She adored the feel of his hands on her, whether in tender caresses like these or in rougher embraces no less devoted than this one. The fire crackled, releasing its soothing scent, and outside, the daylight began to wane, casting shadows across the bath.
“Wait, I’ll light a few candles.”
Faramir rose and moved around the room, lighting several long beeswax candles that filled the space with a faint honeyed fragrance. Éowyn stirred.
“Leave them. It would spare you from seeing these graceless limbs.”
“Oh, foolish wife! Even were you withered like an apple forgotten in a cook’s basket, I could not love you less than I do now.”
Faramir returned to her side, pressing a soft kiss to her brow.
“You always manage to charm with those lofty words of yours. But not even the sweetest Elvish songs could turn back time.”
She said this with a small splash in his direction, to which Faramir laughed heartily and replied:
“No, time flows ever onward. But it cannot weaken the love I bear for you. Now, raise your arms.”
With deliberate movements, Faramir passed a cloth infused with fragrant foam under her arms, along the curve of her shoulders, collarbones, and neck. She inhaled the delicate fragrance rising from the water, pleased at the thought that it would soon linger upon her skin. A strand of Faramir’s dark hair brushed against her shoulder as he leaned closer to her ear.
“Stand,
melethril nîn
(my love): I want to rinse you thoroughly.”
“But you’ll be soaked!”
Éowyn protested, for she still enjoyed the warmth of the bath and wasn’t quite ready to reveal the scars and marks that time had etched upon her. Faramir smiled, pulling his hair back and fastening it in a knot behind his head.
“A small price I’ll gladly pay for so fair a sight! Come now, don’t make me do all the work.”
He kissed her shoulder playfully, making her shiver. Éowyn sighed, then rose to her feet, placing a hand on her husband’s shoulder to steady herself. Laughing, she wrapped her arms around him in defiance, just as he had prophesied.
“Oh,
dagnirig
!”
Faramir muttered in playful resignation, using the Sindarin word which she knew meant little bratt. To appease him, she showered his lips and jaw with light kisses. Smiling, Faramir rose to fetch another bucket of warm water, while Éowyn wrung out her hair. Turning back to her, he nearly caught his breath: water ran down her alabaster skin, and her hair, gathered to one side, draped over her shoulder. To his eyes, she appeared like a Maia risen from the waters.
Éowyn looked at him, unsettled by the intensity of his gaze. She felt vulnerable, as though he saw something in her that she herself would never deem worthy of such adoration. Faramir shook his head with a gentle smile. He stepped closer, dipping a cloth in clean water, then softly swept it over her arms, her shoulders, down her body. Silence thick with intimacy stretched between them, filled only by the delicate dripping of rain and the faint hiss of candles. Without breaking their gaze, Faramir knelt and brushed his lips tenderly against her abdomen.
“Do you see? Always you bring me to my knees, Éowyn.”
Her cheeks flushed, and despite herself, she felt flattered, a sweet confusion stirring within her. Meeting her reflection in his adoring eyes, she finally saw herself as radiant and beautiful—an image that banished all her shame, leaving only the knowledge of a love that saves and heals.
writing_prompt: After a long illness, Éowyn struggles with lingering vulnerability and self-doubt, but Faramir’s unwavering devotion and tender care remind her of the healing power of love. Write a scene that explores their quiet intimacy and the strength they find in each other.

post_title: On a warm summer evening, Princess Lothíriel and King Éomer meet in Minas Tirith, discovering hidden feelings and mutual attraction amidst Queen Arwen's festivities.
comment:
On that warm July evening, Merethrond, the Great Hall of Feasts, echoed with cheerful chatter, the clinking of glasses, the clangor of cutlery, ringing laughter, and the notes of musical instruments that rose high into the air. The nobility of Gondor and neighboring realms had gathered in the Royal Citadel of Minas Tirith for one of the many celebrations hosted by Queen Arwen. After the material and moral ruins left by the War and the many years of Darkness, much had to be rebuilt in terms of human and diplomatic relationships. Alliances were formed, and marriages were arranged. Nothing widened hearts like a good Gondorian meal and a sweet Elvish dance, according to Arwen, and Aragorn wholeheartedly agreed. The little ones from the Shire had taught them that life was a whirlwind of adventures, shared meals, cheerful songs, and love always worth living.
However, a delicate figure slipped away from the Hall of Feasts, blending into the shadows of the night. She wandered through the great halls in search of silence and peace, crossed one of the stone courtyards, and circled the fountain without being seen by the guards standing before the flowering White Tree. She reached the building designated to host dignitaries and stopped by a window, seeking relief from the burdens of her princely condition. Seated on a bench, she gazed at the flowers in the small garden before her. The night was warm, and the constellations of Menelvagor with the red Borgil and Remmirath farther north shone brightly, and even the star Eärendil glowed faintly as if veiled by the sky. Not a breath of breeze stirred the leaves and petals: anemones, asphodels, roses, and golden laburnums drooped their heads, their colors dull as if they too were lifeless from the heat. With a sigh, Lothíriel slipped off her uncomfortable yet delicate slippers and for a moment enjoyed the cool marble under her feet.
She was warm, her hairpins pricked her head, and her blue dress, encrusted with pearls, weighed heavily on her shoulders. As the princess of Dol Amroth, she was devoted to following all the protocols her rank demanded, but she was tired and would have preferred to spend the evening in her quarters or, better yet, at the small summer house her family owned in Cobas Haven, a place of refuge for holidays. But something, or rather someone, kept her there: the handsome King of Rohan, to whom her father had promised her, and the hope that he would accept her hand, if not for her beauty, at least for the dynastic advantages their union would bring.
It was thus that Éomer saw her: the princess sitting by the window, her figure slightly hunched, her long black hair gracefully styled in an updo, with a few artfully scattered curls. However, Éomer’s heart sank as he noticed the unhappy expression on her beautiful round face resting on her hand. It seemed to him that it was not right to spy on her so covertly, despite Lothíriel's enchanting and alluring beauty. So, he cleared his throat and revealed his presence:
"Princess, there you are at last!"
Lothíriel started in surprise at hearing him speak so suddenly. Éomer, noticing her distress, softened his usual stern expression:
"Oh, I apologize if I startled you, my lady."
Lothíriel quickly composed herself, internally thanking her training, and nonchalantly attempted to slip her slippers back on. With a smile, she replied:
"No disturbance, I was merely lost in thought. Were you looking for me, Your Majesty?"
"Indeed, your lord father sent your brothers to find you, and Amrothos enlisted my aid."
"You would not have come to seek me otherwise?"
Lothíriel's grey eyes sparkled with mischief. Éomer stepped slightly closer to her and allowed a small smile:
"Would you have allowed yourself to be found? The way you slipped away from the reception, I had the impression you sought a more secluded place."
Lothíriel sighed, torn between revealing her woes sincerely or showing only the nobler side of her role:
"In truth, I am a bit tired and overheated."
Éomer nodded, appreciating her candor, being himself accustomed to such directness. They remained silent for a moment, Lothíriel gazing at the starry night and Éomer observing her profile. Then she said:
"At this time of year, a sea breeze always blows at home: it carries the aromatic scent of coastal plants and the salty fragrance of shells and seaweed. Here it is so sultry that I cannot even smell the flowers."
Lothíriel wrinkled her nose as if she could perceive the scents she had evoked: broom, arbutus, honeysuckle, laurel, and rockrose with small white and pink flowers, and the briny aroma of seaweed mixed with the balsamic scent of maritime pines.
Éomer shifted his weight from one foot to the other and scratched his blonde beard, uncertain. Though he was educated as a noble warrior should be, he had been too occupied with his role as Marshal of the Mark and was more accustomed to decapitating Orcs than courting noble maidens.
"Do you miss home, Princess?"
Lothíriel turned to him and shook her head, smiling as a few black locks escaped their pins. She did not want to give the impression of being unable to maintain composure regarding her homeland, so she quickly replied:
"Oh, not at all. I am merely bored, and the excess of emotions loosens my tongue without restraint. Please, do not heed my foolish words."
However, now that Lothíriel had mentioned it, Éomer could not take his eyes off her full, rosy lips. He wondered if they would be as sweet and juicy as the fruits they resembled. He chastised himself for that ungentlemanly thought and sighed, flaring his nostrils.
"If that is the case, allow me to escort you to your quarters. I will ensure that no one will reproach your early departure."
Lothíriel nodded, appreciating Éomer's kindness. She rose from the bench, gathered her things, and approached the King of Rohan.
"Thank you, my lord. It is a most courteous gesture."
"I am not entirely unfamiliar with good manners, though I spend much of my time among soldiers and horses."
Éomer replied stiffly, returning to his usual stern demeanor and pressing his lips together beneath his beard. Lothíriel covered her mouth with her hand, mortified:
"Forgive my thoughtlessness, Your Majesty. Naturally, I meant no offense."
The girl's cheeks darkened, revealing her embarrassment. Fascinated by her sincerity and grace, Éomer set aside his natural gruffness and forced a smile. He offered her his arm, and with a sigh, Lothíriel leaned on his solid frame. They walked in silence for a few minutes along the majestic corridors, whose walls were adorned with finely carved bas-reliefs and delicate Elvish tapestries brought in dowry by the queen. The bas-reliefs depicted the epic deeds of the great kings of Gondor, and the tapestries, with their intricate patterns, portrayed scenes from Valinor and Lothlórien, woven with silver and gold threads that gleamed in the torchlight. The high ceiling was supported by elegantly sculpted white marble columns, and here and there, niches contained statues of historical figures, heroes of the past who seemed to watch the two young people as they advanced.
The air was filled with the scent of beeswax and the faint aroma of the medicinal herbs that the court healers used to keep the environment healthy. Éomer’s hand pressed gently on Lothíriel's fingers. He wished he could be as gallant as Théodred, as charming as the Dol Amroth brothers, or as admirable as Lord Aragorn; instead, he desperately sought something to say to the beautiful princess. Something interesting and refined as befitting a lady of her rank, and not the vain and coarse words of a soldier that rose to his lips. For her part, Lothíriel was grateful for the soft torchlight and her amber skin, which partly concealed the heat that rose from her shoulders to her cheeks. The close proximity of the Lord of the Horses, his measured step, and his serious expression intrigued and fascinated her. And even frightened her a little. How could she penetrate the armor of this man, which she now knew was made not only of leather and metal? She was pondering this when she missed a step, and her slipper slipped off her foot.
"I beg your pardon. The dances must have tired me more than I thought."
"I noticed your uncertain steps. If you are in pain, you may take those things off your feet."
The horrified expression on Lothíriel's face was all the response Éomer received. At home, she would not have hesitated to remove her slippers, but Gondorian customs did not permit such improprieties. Éomer snorted in amusement and impulsively asked:
"Your quarters are not far, are they?"
"No, past those arches and left down the corridor. But why... oh!"
With a gesture, Éomer lifted Lothíriel into his arms and resumed their walk. She could have protested vigorously at such audacity, but instead, after a moment of bewilderment, she rested her face on the broad chest of the King. She appreciated his strength and his distinctive scent, the warmth emanating from his chest, the solid robustness of his biceps, and the beat of his heart. She lifted her face and wondered how soft his beard was and if he would ever let her braid his hair. At that thought, Lothíriel’s heart skipped a beat, and before other improper thoughts could disturb her
maidenly mind, Éomer gently set her down before her door.
Lothíriel bowed her head in a courteous nod of thanks while Éomer stood stiffly before her. Only at that moment, in fact, did the Lord of the Horses realize how inappropriate his impulsive gesture had been and how it could be a source of discontent. He would never have wanted to put Lothíriel in a compromising position that could embarrass her. He mumbled something like a good night, and Lothíriel had to stifle a giggle as she watched the mighty King of the Mark practically flee with burning cheeks.
writing_prompt: At a grand feast in Minas Tirith, Princess Lothíriel escapes the stifling festivities for a moment of solitude, only to be discovered by King Éomer of Rohan. What begins as an awkward encounter under the stars soon turns into an unexpected connection between two hearts bound by duty but yearning for something more.
