The Citadel and all of Minas Tirith buzzed with activity: though still scarred by the wounds of war, the Gondorians wasted no time in striving to rebuild and repair the damage. Carts, workers, carpenters, joiners, blacksmiths, and even a few dwarves swarmed in and out, engaged in their labor of reconstruction. Additionally, in a few days' time, the funeral procession for Théoden, King of Rohan, would depart to return his mortal remains to his ancestral lands, making the life of the court quite busy as well.
As a princess, Lothíriel had to oversee the preparations for those who would follow the procession to Rohan. She took her duties very seriously, aware of her destiny and the responsibilities it entailed. Since birth, she had been trained to fulfill her duties as a lady of the castle. She could do sums and write, speak Westron, Sindarin, and Adûnaic. She sat in councils with her father and brothers and even had the right to speak. She knew how to oversee a kitchen and a hall and, if she put in great effort, could even do some embroidery. She knew botany and the properties of plants: medicinal, edible, or poisonous.
She had been taught the art of diplomacy and could discern if a trade contract was favorable or not. She knew how to swim and, thanks to lessons secretly given by her brothers, could also sail a small boat and read the skies. For these reasons, she found herself in Minas Tirith, overseeing all the activities of the traveling Dol Amrothian court, as well as being put on display like a horse at the fair.
Speaking of horses, Lothíriel wrinkled her nose as a waft of manure reached her. She paused to try to orient herself: she had been told to take two left turns and the third corridor on the right. She was convinced she had followed the directions but had evidently become lost in the labyrinthine part of the Citadel. In truth, she was distracted: she had been thinking of nothing but the young King of Rohan and their encounter a few evenings before. She still smiled, recalling Éomer’s embarrassed face when he realized that picking up a high-ranking princess was not a proper gesture. And she felt warm and flustered when she thought of his strong body pressed against hers and the desire to be nestled in his arms again. She retraced her steps and tried turning left, only to find herself in the stables.
She tried to stay calm, despite being in the last place she wanted to be. Although she knew how to ride a horse when necessary, such as during official processions, she had always been apprehensive around those large animals. She appreciated their sleek beauty but found them too sensitive and unpredictable. Her nervousness often reflected on them, making them even more agitated and difficult to manage. Thus, when she heard a snort and the clatter of hooves, Lothíriel jumped, glad the horses' stalls were closed. As she tried to get her bearings and figure out how to retrace her steps, a familiar voice with a heavy accent from the Mark interrupted her thoughts.
“Princess?”
Lothíriel forced herself to appear calm despite her initial agitation and smiled, replying:
“Majesty, we seem to meet in the most unusual places!”
Éomer smiled:
“What brings you to the lower recesses of the Citadel?”
“I was looking for the storerooms, but I fear I am lost.”
“If you don't mind, I would gladly escort you to your destination. But do not fret; it is very easy to get lost in this labyrinth. Even I, who often come to the stables, have found myself disoriented.”
Lothíriel relaxed and took the arm Éomer offered her:
“In that case, I feel less at fault and gladly accept your guidance!”
At that moment, a large brown horse lunged towards the gate of its stall, having caught the scent of its master. Lothíriel, unable to help herself, jumped and squealed in fear.
“Be at ease, that is Firefoot, my horse. He must have caught my scent and probably expects a treat. Allow me to greet him, though I have already done so not long ago.”
Éomer moved, expecting Lothíriel to follow, but she remained rooted to the spot. He narrowed his brown eyes slightly and scratched his beard.
“Are you not curious to see the famous horses of Rohan?”
“Oh, truly I can wait here while you tend to your duty.”
Lothíriel replied nervously, having no intention of venturing into the stables. Éomer's lips stretched into a smile beneath his beard. Once again, the princess showed signs of uncertainty in his presence, not without a certain satisfaction: it was yet another opportunity for him to display himself and court the fair noblewoman. Perhaps to make amends for the misstep of a few evenings prior, though he did not regret it and his arms still nostalgically recalled the sweet weight of the girl. He nudged her gently in a good-natured manner:
“You wouldn’t want to deny the King of Rohan the pleasure of your company, would you?”
He extended his arm, looking at Lothíriel with eyes sparkling with mischief. Éomer was not enthusiastic about his title or the burdens it entailed. He did not feel ready or capable of governing a country: that should have been Théodred’s burden and honor. Yet, in this case, the young man had no qualms about leveraging his title. Sometimes it could be amusing. Lothíriel smiled tightly, unable to refuse a direct request from a king.
“Never! Lead the way, please.”
With one hand she lifted her gown and with the other leaned on Éomer’s arm, who smiled with satisfaction. They ventured into the dim stables, illuminated only by the many high-placed slits. A heavy animal scent filled the air, mitigated only by the smell of fresh hay. Neighs, snorts, and hoofbeats greeted the visitors. Éomer walked confidently, greeting the horses and taking pleasure in the princess’s hand gripping his forearm more tightly.
“Here, this is Firefoot, my companion in arms and faithful steed.”
Lothíriel jumped back when Éomer’s horse enthusiastically thrust its head out to greet its master. Éomer clicked his tongue and stroked the animal between the nostrils. He turned to Lothíriel:
“Would you like to try, my lady?”
Lothíriel raised her hand and tentatively placed it on Firefoot’s muzzle, keeping it still for a moment, awaiting the horse’s reaction. Éomer placed his hand over hers, guiding it gently over the sleek coat. Lothíriel shivered, unsure if it was from the warmth of Éomer’s hand or the pleasure of stroking the horse’s muzzle, which snorted softly, pleased.
“You are fortunate, princess: usually Firefoot is not so accommodating with strangers. In truth, sometimes not even with me!”
Lothíriel chuckled, reassured by the horse’s behavior and thrilled by Éomer’s proximity, who had not yet lifted his hand from hers. He leaned down to her ear:
“I gather you do not frequent stables often. A real pity to deprive yourself of the company of such noble creatures.”
The warm breath of the King tickled Lothíriel’s bare neck, sending a delightful shiver down her spine. She turned, slipping her hand from under Éomer’s.
“Indeed, they are splendid animals, though their company is not my preference.”
Éomer fetched an apple from one of the saddlebags and handed it to the princess to feed the horse. Lothíriel felt scrutinized by the sharp brown eyes watching her intently, with only the creases at the corners betraying Éomer’s secret amusement.
“Yet, the Queen of Rohan is expected to have a certain familiarity with horses: to ride, groom, and manage them completely. After all, we are the Lords of Horses. And so should be their Queen.”
“Are you so certain I will be your Queen?”
Lothíriel’s lips curved into a smile as she observed the confusion on Éomer’s face:
“Ah... but your father has offered...”
“Ada may have proposed, but the final decision rests with me.”
The princess’s eyes sparkled with playful mischief. Éomer quickly recovered from his moment of confusion, a determined smile appearing on his face. He guided Lothíriel to another stall, placing a firm yet gentle hand on her back. He liked the princess, he decided. Not only for her undeniable beauty: Éomer was fascinated by her soft curves and the amber color of her skin, which added an exotic touch to her charm. But also her cheerful and straightforward character, with that hint of Gondorian reserve, uplifted his spirits, and Béma knew how much he needed that. They stopped before a horse less impetuous than Firefoot but equally majestic.
“She is Goldwena, daughter of Snowmane,  Théoden King’s horse.”
Éomer paused for a moment, unable to continue. Lothíriel placed a comforting hand on his arm in silent support. Éomer straightened and gave her a grateful smile. He moved to one of the nearby posts where various stable tools hung and took a curry comb.
“I’ve a feeling that after so many male hands, perhaps this beauty would appreciate a feminine touch. Come, do you know how to groom a horse?”
He handed her the curry comb, waiting for her to take it. Lothíriel accepted the tool with some reluctance, but her curiosity was piqued.
“It would be an honor to learn from you, Éomer King.”
Éomer showed her how to use the curry comb, moving her hand calmly and precisely along the horse’s coat.
“The Rohan’s horses, especially the Mearas, are known for their strength, intelligence, and loyalty. They are direct descendants of the noble horses of Nahar, the steed of the god Oromë. Goldwena, as you see, has a coat that requires careful attention.”
Lothíriel listened intently, replicating Éomer’s movements on Goldwena’s back.
“The horses of Dol Amroth are smaller and lighter,” she responded while continuing to groom. “They need to be agile to run on the sands of our coasts and compact enough to be easily embarked. They do not possess the majesty of the Mearas, but they are equally valiant.”
Éomer nodded, observing with interest how Lothíriel was beginning to gain confidence with the horse. From the saddlebag, he pulled out a carrot and fed it to the animal, stroking her tenderly and murmuring softly:
“Good girl.”
For a moment, Lothíriel imagined what it felt like to be the recipient of such praise, and the thought made her cheeks warm. Her lord father may have arranged the marriage, but while she had the final say, Lothíriel would not refuse the candidate chosen for her. As she watched Éomer out of the corner of her eye, stroking Goldwena’s muzzle, none of the geopolitical considerations that had put her in this position crossed her mind. Her eyes and her heart were already full of Éomer alone.
writing_prompt: A Gondorian princess with a distaste for stables finds herself lost in the labyrinthine halls of Minas Tirith, only to stumble upon the King of Rohan and his spirited horse—sparks fly, but is it the start of a romance or a clash of wills?
